data.title: Amazon Leads Record $110 Billion OpenAI Funding Round. AWS Is Why. — Barrons.com
data.description:
By Mackenzie Tatananni

Amazon.com unveiled a strategic partnership with OpenAI on Friday that includes a $50 billion investment in the ChatGPT maker.

Under the terms of the deal, Amazon Web Services will be the exclusive third-party cloud distribution provider for OpenAI Frontier, which allows users to build, deploy, and manage teams of AI agents. Amazon will make an initial $15 billion investment, with the remaining $35 billion coming after certain conditions are met.

The partners pledged to create a computing environment powered by OpenAI models that will be available for AWS customers "to build generative AI applications and agents at production scale."

OpenAI and Amazon also plan to develop customized models that can power Amazon's customer-facing applications. The agreement comes with a pledge from OpenAI to use 2 gigawatts of capacity from Amazon's Trainium chips.

Amazon shares ticked down 0.8% in premarket trading. Futures tracking the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite declined 1.1%.

OpenAI said separately Friday that it had closed a $110 billion funding round, more than double its $40 billion raise last year. The figure includes $50 billion from Amazon, $30 billion from SoftBank, and $30 billion from Nvidia.

The investment brings OpenAI to a $730 billion pre-money valuation, up from $500 billion in October.

The partnerships with Amazon, Nvidia, and the like "expand our global reach, deepen our infrastructure, and strengthen our balance sheet so we can bring frontier AI to more people, more businesses, and more communities worldwide," OpenAI said in a blog post.

More importantly for investors, the latest funding arrives before a possible OpenAI initial public offering. The company has been eyed as a candidate to go public, with multiple reports suggesting it could make its trading debut as soon as the second half of the year.

The developments come at a time when concerns over artificial-intelligence disruption have reached a fever pitch. Software stocks have been hammered in a broad-based selloff that reflects a deflationary spiral in tech valuations.

Although Nvidia reported blowout earnings on Wednesday, the results failed to assuage investor concerns over the longevity of the AI boom. Shares of the chip maker suffered their worst single-day drop in nearly a year on Thursday.

Write to Mackenzie Tatananni at mackenzie.tatananni@barrons.com

This content was created by Barron's, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. Barron's is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.

data.title: DELL Stock Breaks 100-DMA For First Time In Over Two Months – Here’s Why Analysts Are Bullish
data.description:
Key points:
  • For FY27, Dell expects revenue between $138 billion and $142 billion, with AI-optimized server revenue at $50 billion.
  • JPMorgan raised its price target on Dell to $165 from $155 and kept an ‘Overweight’ rating, according to The Fly.
  • Mizuho said Dell is well-positioned heading into fiscal 2027 due to strong AI demand and higher-margin storage attach opportunities.

Shares of Dell Technologies (DELL) surged more than 18% on Friday and climbed over its 100-day moving average (100-DMA) for the first time since December 12, as investors and analysts lapped up the company’s record quarterly earnings and annual guidance.

Source: TradingView

If the current levels hold at close, DELL shares would record their biggest intraday gain since September 2023.

Dell reported a record fourth quarter revenue of $33.4 billion, up 39% from a year ago, while its diluted earnings per share (EPS) surged 57% to $3.37.

For FY27, the company projected revenue between $138 billion and $142 billion, representing 23% growth at the midpoint of $140 billion. Dell expects full-year EPS of $11.52 at the midpoint. Annual revenue from AI-optimized servers is projected to be about $50 billion, a 103% increase from a year ago.

Low Downside Risk To FY27 Outlook

JPMorgan raised its price target on Dell to $165 from $155 and kept an ‘Overweight’ rating, according to The Fly. Analyst Samik Chatterjee said that Dell’s decision to sharply raise earnings guidance despite higher memory costs shows confidence. He believes this will lead “investors to assume that the downside risks in relation to delivering to the outlook are lower than assumed earlier.”

Mizuho lifted Dell’s price target to $180 from $175 and maintained an ‘Outperform’ rating. The firm said Dell is well-positioned heading into fiscal 2027, supported by strong AI demand and higher-margin storage attach opportunities.

How Did Stocktwits Users React?

Dell’s results generated significant buzz among Stocktwits users as retail sentiment turned ‘extremely bullish’ from ‘bullish’ a day earlier, while message volume increased more than 350% over a 24-hour period as of Friday morning.

One user called the rally “just the beginning.”

https://stocktwits.com/rlaarlaa/message/646099896

Another user said the stock’s valuation is cheap, and the company is the “best in AI infrastructure play.”

https://stocktwits.com/Realtrader77/message/646069375

Year-to-date, the stock has gained around 13%.

data.title: US intends to nominate an American to UN World Food Programme
data.description:
By Daphne Psaledakis

The United States intends to nominate an American to lead the United Nations World Food Programme in coming weeks, a State Department spokesperson said, after Cindy McCain said on Thursday that she intends to step down as head of the program.

"The United States can confirm that it will be nominating a highly-qualified American to lead the ... WFP, continuing America’s tradition of excellence and responsible stewardship of the organization. The candidate will be announced in the coming weeks," the spokesperson said.

The United States is traditionally the largest donor to WFP. The program is headed by an executive director, who is appointed jointly by the U.N. Secretary-General and the director-general of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations for a five-year term, according to the program's website.

A spokesperson for U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

The WFP said on Thursday that McCain would step down in three months.

McCain, 71, widow of the late U.S. Republican Senator John McCain, took up the job in 2023 after serving as U.S. ambassador to the United Nations agencies for food and agriculture.

McCain said in a statement that while she had hoped to finish out her term, her health had not recovered fully. She suffered a mild stroke in October.

data.title: OpenAI Raises $110 Billion — WSJ
data.description:
By Kate Clark

OpenAI has secured commitments totaling $110 billion in new funding, the company said.

The deal, which values the company at $730 billion before the investment, shows investor appetite for the ChatGPT developer remains strong ahead of an expected IPO later this year and reasserts OpenAI's position in an increasingly competitive market.

The financing includes a $30 billion investment from SoftBank and a $50 billion commitment from Amazon.com.

Amazon will invest an initial $15 billion into the company, followed by a $35 billion tranche contingent on certain milestones.

As part of the Amazon deal, OpenAI will buy billions of dollars' worth of Amazon's AI chips. It plans to use the Trainium chips for its new enterprise offering, called Frontier. The deal marks a pivot for OpenAI, which has historically leaned on Nvidia GPUs for compute capacity.

The round also includes $30 billion from Nvidia, after the chipmaker's earlier plan to invest up to $100 billion stalled when some inside the tech giant raised concerns about the deal, the Journal previously reported. OpenAI said additional investors are expected to join the round.

The company also announced that weekly users of its AI coding tool, Codex, have reached 1.6 million, more than tripling since the beginning of the year. OpenAI is planning to go public in the fourth-quarter in what has become a heated race with rival Anthropic to reach the public markets. Earlier this month, Anthropic raised $30 billion at a $380 billion valuation.

The $100 billion raise comes after a year of aggressive dealmaking for OpenAI, including a content-licensing agreement and a $1 billion investment from Disney.

OpenAI has also faced challenges recently, including issuing a "code red" as it works to fend off growing competition from Google and emerging neolabs.

The fresh capital adds to the tens of billions of dollars OpenAI has raised to date from investors including the Abu Dhabi fund MGX, Thrive Capital, Microsoft and SoftBank.

Write to Kate Clark at kate.clark@wsj.com

data.title: Merck, Pfizer Report Positive Results From Combined Bladder-Cancer Trial
data.description:
By Elias Schisgall

Merck & Co.'s Keytruda in combination with an antibody-drug conjugate from Pfizer and Astellas Pharma led to a 47% reduction in the risk of tumor recurrence, progression or death in patients with muscle-invasive bladder cancer in a Phase 3 trial.

Merck and Pfizer said Friday that the combination of enfortumab vedotin, trademarked as Padcev, and Keytruda also led to 79% of patients in the trial being event-free after two years, compared with 66% treated with standard of care chemotherapy.

The drug combination also led to a 35% reduced risk of death, a key secondary endpoint for the trial, the companies said. About 76% of patients in the trial experienced grade 3 or higher adverse events, which the companies said was consistent with prior experiences with the combination.

Merck was recently trading up 1.5% at $121.09 in Friday morning trading. Pfizer gained 0.4%.

"These compelling data, reinforced by the precedented EV-303 results, suggest a transformative opportunity to establish PADCEV plus pembrolizumab as the next standard of care if approved, and provide a meaningful step forward for patients and their families," said Pfizer Chief Oncology Officer Jeff Legos.

The combination of the two treatments is already approved for adult patients with urothelial cancer in the U.S., Europe, and several other countries.

Write to Elias Schisgall at elias.schisgall@wsj.com

data.title: Spanish feminist targeted by AI fakes wants stricter online regulations
data.description:
By David Latona

A Spanish women's rights activist who suffered online abuse, including AI-generated fake nude images, said the government's pledge to regulate social media does not go far enough, calling for anonymous accounts to be made traceable to end impunity for digital violence.

As Europe's push to rein in U.S.-based tech giants is shifting from fines and takedown notices to stiffer measures, Madrid wants to impose a ban on under-16s accessing social media and criminal liability for platform executives who fail to remove illegal or hateful content.

France, Greece and Poland are weighing similar measures after Australia became the first country to block social media for children under 16 in December.

Carla Galeote, a 25-year-old lawyer and prominent online feminist commentator, told Reuters governments were reacting only now because digital violence had become impossible to ignore, although the problem predated AI.

"Social media isn't new - and the violence is brutal, systematic, 24/7," Galeote said. "What hit me hardest wasn't the deepfake, it was going to the police and being told it wasn't even a crime."

She dismissed plans to ban children from social media as "paternalistic", arguing all users, regardless of age, need protection from digital abuse.

Spain's proposed law has sparked backlash from tech company executives, who accuse Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez of threatening free speech. Galeote, however, believes regulation and freedom of expression can coexist.

"It's impossible to think that a man on the street could shout that they'll rape you and nothing happens, but that's what we're seeing online," she said.

Instead of imposing easily absorbable fines, Galeote advocated barring platforms from major markets, like the European Union, for repeated violations.

While defending pseudonymous online use, Galeote emphasized the need for traceable identities behind all accounts.

"Call yourself 'PeppaPig88' if you want - fine. But there has to be a real identity behind that account," she said.
